tn.text: AT: "remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I have no pleasure in them
tn.text: Here the word "them" refers to "years."
The writer describes a house in which various activities stop. This appears to be a metaphor for the human body as it becomes old. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the women who grind cease because they are few
tn.text: "the women who grind grain stop grinding grain because there are few of them"
The writer continues his metaphor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the doors are shut in the street
tn.text: AT: "people shut the doors that lead to the street" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: when men are startled at the voice of a bird
tn.text: AT: "when the voice of a bird startles men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The writer continues his metaphor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "when people no longer desire what they once did naturally" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The "almond tree" is a tree that blossoms in the winter with white flowers.

tn.ref: Then man goes to his eternal home
tn.text: This refers to death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: the mourners go down the streets
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) that mourners go down the streets to attend a funeral, or 2) that mourners go down the streets to the house of the person who is about to die.
"remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: before the silver cord is cut ... or the water wheel is broken at the well
tn.text: The writer compares death to various broken items. Death will break the body just as suddenly as people accidentally break these items while they are using them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"someone cuts the silver cord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"someone crushes the golden bowl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"someone shatters the pitcher " (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"someone breaks the water wheel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "dust" refers to the human body that has decomposed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"everything only lasts a short time, like steam that disappears." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"thought much about and arranged" or "thought much about and wrote down"

tn.ref: The words of wise people ... taught by one shepherd
tn.text: The writer compares the teacher who uses his words to instruct people to a shepherd who uses his tools to lead his flock. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The words of wise people are like goads
tn.text: "Wise people encourage us to act, like a sharp stick encourages an animal to move." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Like nails driven deeply are the words of the masters in collections of their proverbs
tn.text: "Like you can depend on a nail that has been driven deep, you can depend on proverbs written by wise people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: the words of the masters in collections of their proverbs
tn.text: "the words of those who are experts on collections of proverbs"

tn.ref: which are taught by one shepherd
tn.text: "which one shepherd teaches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the making of many books, which has no end
tn.text: "people will never stop making many books"
"makes the person tired" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"the final conclusion on the matter"
AT: "after you have heard everything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
